This is just the beginning, not the end. ¬† Thanks to SCOTUS, the reproductive health of millions of Americans is in the hands of politicians and judges. ¬† Now, will the Court clean up some of the mess it created or double down?

We don't know how this will turn out. ¬† SCOTUS's Dobbs decision opened the floodgates for anti-abortion radicals to sow chaos and confusion across the country, coming after reproductive freedom after freedom.

So what does this all mean for today? ¬† Today, SCOTUS is hearing arguments to determine whether the FDA's evidence-based actions to expand access to mifepristone will stand, or whether it'll undermine FDA authority and place restrictions on mifepristone without scientific reason.

Limiting access to mifepristone would impact every single state. ¬† Over 64.5 million people nationwide would face increased barriers to abortion care, all whileRepublicans continue their cruel and extremist crusade to ban abortion across the country.
Let me be clear: while we wait for SCOTUS to issue a ruling, mifepristone remains available. ¬† But that could all change depending on what SCOTUS decides.

Immediately after the Texas ruling, a Washington state federal judge issued a contrary decision. Chaos and confusion erupted across the country. ¬† With zero clarity on mifepristone's availability, SCOTUS suspended the lower court decisions until it could decide the issue itself.
This is yet another tactic in the far-right‚Äôs mission to force an outright ban on abortion nationwide‚Äî weaponizing our courts to push their ideological agendas on the American people.

Last year, a Trump-appointed federal judge in Texas who was selected by anti-abortion plaintiffs‚Äîa practice known as judge-shopping‚Äîissued a ruling revoking the FDA's approval of mifepristone, nearly banning the pill nationwide. ¬† Yes, even in states where abortion remains legal.

The FDA approved mifepristone as safe and effective in 2000, and then made the pill more accessible in 2016 and 2021 by allowing the pill to be: ¬† ‚ñ™Ô∏è dispensed in retail pharmacies and by mail ‚ñ™Ô∏è prescribed by more certified providers ‚ñ™Ô∏è prescribed through telehealth appointments

When Dobbs was decided, we knew chaos and confusion would be unleased across the country, and we're seeing it now. ¬† Mifepristone has been safely used for more than 20 years, accounting for over 50% of all abortions in the U.S. Now, access to this pill is at risk.

Eliminating Chevron would prevent the government from fulfilling its most basic functions and allow big businesses and billionaires to further stack the deck in their favor‚Äîat the expense of working Americans and small businesses.

For example, in 2022 when considering EPA clean air regulations, the conservative-majority Supreme Court applied the "major-questions" doctrine to get around the Chevron doctrine‚Äîundermining the decisions of EPA experts and weakening critical environmental regulations.

This is all part of the far-right's larger agenda to capture the courts to advance its ideological agenda by overturning decades-long precedent, sowing dysfunction and undermining Congressional intent and the federal government‚Äôs ability to implement federal law
Overturning Chevron would enable individual judges to limit or overturn agency decisions, giving little to no deference to such decisions.
The Chevron doctrine recognizes the Congress delegates authority to technical experts at federal agencies selected by Congress to implement federal laws, in line with Congress‚Äôs intent.

This Black History Month, let these stories inspire you to help us build a fairer and more just Michigan for the future.

As a grad student at the University of Michigan, Joe Perkins was the first Freedom Rider to be arrested after he requested a shoeshine at a whites-only shoe stand. After two days in jail, he rejoined the group and led the Greyhound Riders, whose bus was burned in Alabama.

After the Montgomery Bus Boycotts, Rosa Parks moved north and made Detroit her home. She continued to advocate for youth empowerment and civil rights and was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Clinton, the highest honor awarded to civilians.

He has been a significant part of my life for almost 60 years.¬† We will deeply miss this very good and decent man.
For years, John, Ken, my classmate Mark, and I have gone to the Reds opening day game . We will go again this year, but it will seem strange without him.

And, when you went to his house, you would so many times find him working on something for his wife Kathy or his children or grandchildren. John was a Reds, Bengals, and OSU Buckeyes fan, although I believe he still had some affection for the San Francisco Bay Area teams.
John would do anything for anybody. I can‚Äôt count the times he has come to our rescue and fixed or repaired something for us.
In high school, John was a good runner.¬† We still have a movie Fran took of John running the Mile in the State Championship at the old track at OSU stadium.
At his home near Clifton Gorge, he created his own sanctuary, planting many different trees and designing and building beautiful little ponds for his Koi and goldfish.

We had the chance to watch John and Ken work when they built our daughter Alice & her husband Nick's house down the road from our home. When the Struewing brothers built a house, they built the house!¬† While they used a few subs, they did the bulk of the physical work themselves.

He spent most of his life building houses, starting at a very young age by helping his dad, who was a builder.¬†He spent 20 years in California, first working for a landscape architect & then as a carpenter, before returning to Ohio to work with his brother Ken in building homes.

Fran remembers one time her dad told John when he was about 12 to tear apart an engine and get it running but to make sure there were no parts left when he was done!¬† And after John did put it together, there were no parts left, and the engine actually ran!
Like the rest of his family, John was a tireless worker.¬† He could fix anything -- from a clock to a car to a sweeper.

We lost Fran‚Äôs brother John this week.¬† He was 72. When Fran and I were married, I was blessed with five new brothers and sisters.¬† John was the fourth of Fran‚Äôs parents' six children. https://t.co/9cpwpkQDJm
